data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A rhizomatous herb (Elettaria cardamomum) native to South Asia, having capsular fruits with aromatic seeds used as a spice or condiment.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The capsules or seeds of this plant.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of several plants of the related genus Amomum, used as a substitute for cardamom.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: One of the capsules of different species of plants of the genera Amomum and Elettaria, natural order Zingiberaceæ: generally used in the plural.
The aromatic fruit, or capsule with its seeds, of several plants of the Ginger family growing in the East Indies and elsewhere, and much used as a condiment, and in medicine.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: A rhizomatous herb which produces cardamoms, esp. <spn>Elettaria Cardamomum</spn> and several species of Amomum.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: The aromatic seed of this plant, used as a <xref>spice</xref>, baking, also in <xref>curry powder</xref> in Asian and Arabic cuisine, as well as in Northern Europe and in many parts of the world and cultures.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: aromatic seeds used as seasoning like cinnamon and cloves especially in pickles and barbecue sauces
